Dickinson Public Schools Names Randy Cranston as Dickinson High School Dean of Students.

Randy Cranston was born in raised in Hatton, ND. He attended undergraduate school at the University of Mary and received his Masters from the University of Phoenix. For the last three years, he has been the principal for Watford City High School and currently serves on the Department of Public Instruction Principals Cabinet.

Before becoming head principal, Cranston was the assistant principal and activities director for five years. He also served as the head basketball coach for 14 years, where he earned the state Class B Coach of the Year in 2008.
He is married to Jenna Cranston, who will teach 1st grade at Heart River Elementary. He has three boys Britton (Jr), Boston (7th), and Beckett (5th).

Welcome to the DPS team, Randy!

Dickinson Public Schools Names Amanda Kuhn as Dickinson Middle School Assistant Principal.

It is with great pleasure we announce Amanda Kuhn has accepted the position of assistant principal of DMS. Kuhn has been working in education for 12 years.

Before moving to Dickinson, she lived in Devils Lake, where she worked at the North Dakota School for the Deaf as a Dorm Counselor, an academic advisor for Mayville State University, and then as the Disability Services Coordinator and Academic Advisor for Lake Region State College.

She has worked as a School Counselor for Dickinson Public Schools for the last five years—first at Hagen Junior High, and now at Dickinson Middle School. Her educational background is in Psychology, Counseling, and Educational Leadership. Kuhn lives in Dickinson with her husband of 10 years and their two kids.

She is looking forward to my new role and continuing to work with students, families, and staff in this new capacity.

Mrs. Kuhn will assume her new role on July 1.

Dickinson Public Schools Names Shawn Leiss as Director of Student Services.

It is with great pleasure we announce Shawn Leiss has accepted the position as Director of Student Services. Leiss has been on the front lines serving students for the past 30 years.

He has served students in a number of capacities, including resource teacher, social studies teacher, alternative school teacher, coach, elementary principal, middle school principal and secondary principal. He has been with Dickinson Public Schools for the past 18 years.

He and his wife have three children; two have completed college and one will be graduating from DHS this year. He looks forward to working with the Dickinson community to ensure a high-quality education for ALL students.

Mr. Leiss will assume his new role on July 1.

It is with great pleasure we announce Randy Muffley has accepted the position as principal for Heart River Elementary.

Randy Muffley has been a passionate educator for 25 years. He has served 19 years as a middle school principal and elementary principal. He is an adjunct professor with Concordia University.

He has two children in college and recently celebrated his 25th wedding anniversary. He is thrilled to be coming to Heart River Elementary and working with the great staff, students and community to continue to achieve great things together.

Welcome to the DPS team, Randy!

DHS Prom Attendees: Prom was rescheduled for May 2 and we mentioned that we would make a decision on the status of that date by April 17. We have decided to postpone prom again to a later date. A survey will be sent to all juniors and seniors that planned on attending. The survey will be sent to your Google Classroom 2020 and 2021. In that survey, we have optional dates for you to select. We expect to make another decision on the status of prom the first week of May in conjunction with a decision on graduation. Expect the survey to be in your Google classroom no later than Monday afternoon.

This month the library media specialists are celebrating National Reading Month with our students. This week, John Steven Gurney is visiting our schools to share more about illustration and creating a story.

He has illustrated over 140 chapter books, including the A to Z Mysteries, the Bailey School Kids, and The Calendar Mysteries series. He has illustrated board games, advertising, posters, puzzles, and a shopping bag for the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day parade. John has worked as a caricature artist from Atlantic City to Las Vegas, and on the streets of New York City, but primarily in New England.

Each school in our district is working to become Level 1 High Reliability School (HRS) Certified this year.

According to Marzano Resources, the framework, based on 40 years of educational research, defines five progressive levels of performance that a school must master to become a HRS—where all students learn the content and skills they need for success in college, careers, and beyond.

This morning, administrators from each building reviewed their Level 1 Certification plans with peers. The Marzano team will be visiting all schools in April to discuss each plan and award certification to those that meet the criteria.

To learn more about the HRS process, check out: https://www.marzanoresources.com/hrs/high-reliability-schools

#DPSpride
shared_text:
Dickinson High School CHEER
February 9 at 6:27 PM ·

Nationals was a whirlwind with wall-to-wall bows. Over 750 teams and thousands of competitors. Competition was an intense 15 hour day. We were on pins and needles as we waited to hear if we had advanced each round. We are cheerleaders so as exhilarating as it is to hear your team announced each time, it was sobering to see teams around us cope with not moving on. At this level of competition every single team is top notch. Every person there has put in tons of work and heart to get there.
When we finally got to Finals round announcements and they called us, we were crazy excited and honored to be in the top 11 in the nation! All along we wanted to represent ND and our school and community well and to make you all proud.
These beautiful athletes are bringing home some hardware. They earned 8th!!! We couldn't have done it without our parents, community, sponsors, school administration , teachers and friends.
Thank you to each one of you who encouraged, supported and believed in us.
